intro: Rafnia retroflexa, commonly known as the redroot false hellebore, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Araceae family and is characterized by its dark green, waxy leaves and striking red-tipped spathes. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that develop into berries, which are toxic to humans and livestock. Rafnia retroflexa thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and wetlands. Due to its toxicity, it is often avoided by herbivores, which helps it survive in competitive plant communities.
